channel.title: Authors on The DAISy Lab @ NC State
channel.description: Recent content in Authors on The DAISy Lab @ NC State

item.description:
The DAISy (Digital Agroecology and Intelligent Systems) Lab advances technical and human-centered design approaches for robotic and sensor systems to monitor agricultural and natural processes, while ensuring these systems are usable and adopted. Research in the DAISy Lab is done at the intersection of sensors and robotics, data analytics, and decision support, with a focus on technology development.

Dr. Sierra Young is an Assistant Professor in the Biological and Agricultural Engineering Department at North Carolina State University. Broadly speaking, her research focuses around the use of electronics, robotics, and automation for sensing and sense-making in natural and agricultural systems. She has expertise in deploying unmanned systems (including land, air, and surface vehicles) for hydrologic, environmental, and phenotyping applications.

Evan is four years into the undergraduate program in Biological and Agricultural Engineering with a concentration in Bioprocessing Engineering at NC State. He is currently working on developing a scanning table for hyperspectral imaging, and measuring soil stress via deployment of UAVs. Previous projects include the development of a protein powder from sweet potato leaves, the anti-oceanic-piracy fish stink bomb, and various projects at UNCG’s Virtual Environment for Assessment and Rehabilitation Lab. Evan’s current academic interests are robotics, bio-manufacturing, programming and fermentation.

Nicole is a 4th year undergraduate student at NC State, working towards a B.S. in Computer Engineering and minoring in Art and Design. She is currently conducting signal processing and computer vision research, working on fisheye and stereo image processing. She focuses her studies on the intersection of art and science, more specifically, exploring the impact of perspective and our assumptions in the sciences.

William is a junior Computer Engineering undergraduate student at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. His interests include digital design, FPGAs, and embedded systems. He has experience working with Arduino, Vivado (VHDL), and object-oriented C++ programming from school and personal projects.
